flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
The furnace style built here is called a "reverberatory" furnace, which just means that the furnace itself is used as a big crucible and is tilted to pour the aluminum out. As such, a high-temperature refractory (a sort of concrete) will be needed to ensure that molten aluminum doesn't eat through and end up all over! Insulating firebricks, while not necessary, are recommended to hasten the speed of melting the aluminum and to keep propane prices down.

You'll need something to put these firebricks and refractory in, of course. I used an old 14 gallon air receiver I had lying around, but a similarly sized steel tank of any sort should work. You'll also need to build a scaffolding to support the tang, something to use as hinges, and a burner, propane tank and hose. Another thing you'll need is something to catch and hold the liquid aluminum; I used a stainless steel bucket with a long handle built in to keep it far away from the operator. But that's basically it.

lines.text: First, find yourself a steel tank. This one is a 14 gallon tank, maybe two feet long and a foot wide in diameter.
lines.text_raw: First, find yourself a steel tank. This one is a 14 gallon tank, maybe two feet long and a foot wide in diameter.

lines.text: Cut it in two lengthwise, this will provide you with a bottom "cup" portion and a lid. Don't cut it right in half though, the lid can be much thinner than the cup portion in the bottom. Measure the diameter of the tank and cut it at about the two-thirds' mark. A 12" diameter tank should be cut at 8" and so on.
lines.text_raw: Cut it in two lengthwise, this will provide you with a bottom "cup" portion and a lid. Don't cut it right in half though, the lid can be much thinner than the cup portion in the bottom. Measure the diameter of the tank and cut it at about the two-thirds' mark. A 12" diameter tank should be cut at 8" and so on.

lines.text: After cutting the tank in half, get some sheet steel to make into a spout for your tank. Bend it into a half-circle, then hold it up to the lower portion of the tank and mark the inside with paint, so you know where to cut the opening. Leave a 1/4" strip on the inside when you cut though, so you have something to weld to.

lines.text: Hopefully you can do a cleaner job than me, but weld your spout onto the front of the tank after cutting out a space.
lines.text_raw: Hopefully you can do a cleaner job than me, but weld your spout onto the front of the tank after cutting out a space.

lines.text: Find something to use for your frame to hold up your furnace (I used 1" square steel tubing) and weld two arms onto the lower portion of your tank. Before you do weld them on though, you'll want to drill holes horizontally through the arms near the spout. These will be used to hold the bolts for your hinges used to tilt the furnace up. If you zoom in on the second picture, you can see where I put my holes.

lines.text: I'll have to ask that you forgive me jumping ahead with the pictures, but I don't have one of the frame by itself. You will need to build a frame at this point, which keeps everything stable. More on that in the next slide.

lines.text: Again, please excuse the jumping ahead with the pictures, they're only to demonstrate roughly what the frame should look like. You'll want something that keeps the bottom of the tank about 5" or 6" off of the ground.

lines.text: You also want the base of the frame to be longer and wider than the tank itself to keep the furnace steady.

lines.text: While you have the tank and your welding stuff out, take the time to make a handle for the lid out of some rebar or something similar. Also make some hinges for the rear of the tank, so you can lift it up to put aluminum in and whatnot.

lines.text: Also, you'll want to weld a black iron pipe in to hold your burner. I used a 2.25" black iron pipe and cut it flush with the bottom of the lid and welded it in at a 45 degree angle, pointing into the back of the furnace. This, though seeming counter intuitive, actually ensures that all the aluminum sitting in the back gets melted.

I used a 2.25" black iron pipe and cut it flush with the bottom of the lid and welded it in at a 45 degree angle, pointing into the back of the furnace. This, though seeming counter intuitive, actually ensures that all the aluminum sitting in the back gets melted.

lines.text: Now that you've got all of your welding out of the way, it's time to put the firebrick in (if you elect to do so). You want to line most of the interior of the tank with them, but leave a gap at the tops, so you can cover the top inch or two with refractory to keep the aluminum from eating the firebricks. You can also line the lid with firebrick as well, and it should add some insulation value.

lines.text: I bought a few cases of 3" firebrick and cut them in half with a junky old tablesaw blade for 1.5" because it was cheaper. If you elect to do this, or any cutting of firebrick, please do it outdoors with a mask because the dust is considered a carcinogen.

lines.text: I welded bent nails to the interior of the tank to secure the bricks in place long enough to get some refractory over them, and they also anchor the refractory in place so it doesn't go anywhere with all the movement of the furnace. Once all that is done...

lines.text: You'll need to make a plug now. It's going to make a hollow spot in your refractory that holds the aluminum. I used some wood glued together, then turned on the lathe to make a wine bottle shaped plug.  An unintended consequence of this was that the bottleneck catches a lot of dross (layer of oxidized aluminum that sits on top) when pouring, so yay.

guide.summary: This is an excellent project for learning some basic metalworking skills using tools such as a welder, mill/drill, lathe and more. It is a fairly time intensive project, and will probably run you upwards of $200, but it is well worth it.
guide.title: Build your very own aluminum furnace!
